fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An article about slip dresses in the latest edition of our twice-yearly magazine The Fashion (Let it slip, 5 March, page 76) said that Undressed: A Brief History of Underwear, an exhibition opening in April at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, features a dress by John Galliano for Dior that Princess Diana wore to the Met Ball in 1996. The exhibition does not feature a dress worn by Diana, but does include another dress by Galliano, from his autumn/winter 1996 collection for Givenchy. • We were mistaken in saying that the Shankly hotel in Liverpool, which we described as a temple to the memory of the former Liverpool manager Bill Shankly, was owned by the son of the chairman of Liverpool’s Merseyside rivals, Everton FC. The hotel’s owner, Lawrence Kenwright, is not the son of Bill Kenwright (British boltholes, 5 March, page 4, Travel). • An article about the six-part thriller series Undercover, which begins next month on BBC1, said incorrectly that it would be the first primetime British drama to feature two black actors in the lead roles (TV drama will be first to have two black leads, 9 March, page 5). • Other recently corrected articles include: Ten Years – the terrifying vision of Hong Kong that Beijing wants obscured Why Ukraine needs Russia more than ever Keith Jeffery obituary Calls grow to label attacks on Middle East Christians as genocide FBI quietly changes its privacy rules for accessing NSA data on Americans World’s highest number of domains? The South Pacific nation of Tokelau Finland ranked world’s most literate nation
